author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: Even the Army Couldn’t Keep Them Apart
description: Rabbi Michael Geoffrey Cohen had 10 months left on his military contract when he met Sharon Leona Poczter. But after a marathon first date, they never fully parted.
content: [Click here to binge read this week’s featured couples.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz, Alanis Thames, Alan Blinder and Scott Miller
title: N.C.A.A. Men’s Tournament: Purdue Looks Sharp in Its Opening Game
description: Yale’s attempts to slow down the Boilermakers’ offense proved futile. In other first-round games, Illinois and Miami won in thrillers and Duke got past Cal State Fullerton.
content: MILWAUKEE — To understand what type of afternoon it was for Purdue (and for Yale), consider a moment when the ball was poked loose from Yale, which led to a break that allowed Jaden Ivey to string together a few long strides and spring high above the rim to grasp Mason Gillis’s alley-oop pass.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Knvul Sheikh
title: Who Should Get a 4th Covid Shot?
description: Experts say that the most vulnerable would benefit from a second booster soonest.
content: As coronavirus case counts continue to plummet across the United States, people’s immunity may be declining, too. Several studies have found that while mRNA booster shots have been successful at preventing hospitalization and death, their effectiveness against infections is waning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: 6 Things We’ll Keep From Pandemic Life
description: Masks when we’re sick, bikes for everyone, and new respect for workers.
content: On Nov. 17, 1918, The New York Times published a lengthy interview with the city’s health commissioner, Royal S. Copeland, titled “Epidemic Lessons Against Next Time.” Dr. Copeland, who a few years later would become a United States senator, spoke about the city’s comparative success combating the Spanish Flu, which at that point, although it had killed nearly 20,000 people, had caused considerably less devastation than in other major cities. Dr. Copeland credited this outcome in large part to systems and habits put in place during previous public-health crises. Even a century earlier, there were, in other words, always takeaways.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: Pasta Alla Vodka, but Make It Beans
description: Ali Slagle takes the classic dish and gives it a 2022 update with chickpeas and kale.
content: We have recipe recommendations this week, as always, but we also have something more exciting for you: restaurant recommendations. Please say hello to Where to Eat, a new weekly newsletter by Nikita Richardson, a wonderful editor on the Food and Cooking team who always knows where to go and what’s good in New York City. Sign up here to start receiving it on March 22, and please note that it’s available to everyone for four weeks, but after that it’s exclusively for Times news subscribers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Siegel Bernard
title: Credit Companies Will Remove Stains From Repaid Medical Debts
description: Debts that are paid off after they go to collections will be removed, instead of staying on a credit reports for up to seven years, Equifax, Experian and TransUnion announced.
content: Equifax, Experian and TransUnion — the giant credit-reporting companies that each keep files on roughly 200 million Americans — said on Friday that they will soon wipe away credit stains created by certain medical debts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Jeanette Wagner, Who Globalized the Estée Lauder Brand, Dies at 92
description: Meticulous in building relationships, she helped open new markets for the cosmetics company, notably in the Soviet Union, as head of its international operations.
content: Jeanette Sarkisian Wagner, both a merchant and a diplomat for Estée Lauder, who popularized the brand’s high-end lipsticks and perfumes among the women of the Soviet Union and China during the rising globalization and free trade of the 1980s and ’90s, died on Feb. 26 in Manhattan. She was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Wall
title: Returning From the Peace Corps to Find Love Close to Home
description: Following a two-year term in Zambia, Holly Van Groll returned to Texas and re-encountered Gregg Bennett, a friend from high school, on a dating app.
content: Online dating felt like a foreign concept to Holly Van Groll when she returned from a more than two year term with the Peace Corps in Zambia, where she lived without electricity and the nearest internet connection was a four-hour bus ride away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliet Macur
title: Knocked Down by Covid in Beijing, Vincent Zhou Is Getting Back Up
description: Zhou missed the men’s individual event at the Olympics because of the coronavirus. He is trying to shake off the memory in hopes of excelling at the figure skating world championships.
content: After a lifetime of training for the Olympics and making it there as a figure skater twice, Vincent Zhou now has moments when it’s too painful for him to think about the Winter Games, or to even go near his skates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Wall
title: A Heart So Full, Her Chipped Teeth Were an Afterthought
description: Kyra Friedell thought she’d never date a Catholic. But Alexander Fernandez, who saw her through personal tragedy (and a beer-bottle knock to the mouth), proved her wrong.
content: Binge more Vows columns here and read all our wedding, relationship and divorce coverage here.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Listening and Clapping
description: What do you know or think you know about this image and where it is from?
content: What do you know or think you know about this image and where it is from? How does it relate to or comment on society or current events? What is your opinion of its message?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Running Stars Are Racing in New York City, and It’s Not the Marathon
description: The New York City Half Marathon is scheduled to be run on Sunday for the first time in three years, and a number of prominent names will be at the starting line.
content: Last December, Sam Grotewold, who leads the professional running program at New York Road Runners, started scratching out a list of people he hoped to lure to the New York City Half Marathon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Chase and Rachel Cericola
title: How to Make Your Second Home Smarter, Safer and More Sustainable
description: From security systems to thermostats to window treatments, modern technology can take the anxiety out of maintaining a home from afar.
content: Anyone fortunate enough to own a second home knows that the solace of a private retreat can fade once the worries surface — all made worse by added distance. An empty home is a vulnerable home, after all, be it from drips, leaks, floods, fires, ice, wind, burglars or bears (so many bears). That’s why smart home devices — wireless appliances and electronics that can communicate with one another and connect via the internet — can be an effective salve, if not an outright cure-all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere
title: Moderna asks the F.D.A. for authorization for a second booster for all adults.
description: The request is significantly broader than one from Pfizer, which sought another shot only for adults age 65 and older.
content: Moderna said late Thursday that it asked the Food and Drug Administration for emergency authorization of a second booster of its coronavirus vaccine for all adults, a significantly broader request than Pfizer and BioNTech filed for their shot this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Clear Indication
description: Claire Rimkus and Brooke Husic offer us a lively Friday puzzle.
content: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Claire Rimkus and Brooke Husic have been constructors in the crossword community for a while, and they have both had puzzles published in The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Once Motorcade Pals, Congressman and Photographer Are Now Public Foes
description: Pete Souza, the former White House photographer-turned-Trump troll, now uses his popular Twitter feed almost exclusively to ridicule Representative Ronny Jackson, the former White House doctor-turned-Trump acolyte.
content: WASHINGTON — They were once seatmates in the spare limousine of the White House motorcade, traveling the globe together as part of the president’s inner circle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Goldstein
title: Opponents Call It the ‘Don’t Say Gay’ Bill. Here’s What It Says.
description: The Florida bill limits what educators can say about gender and sexuality, and could affect mental health services for all students.
content: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida is expected to sign House Bill 1557, which supporters call the “Parental Rights in Education” bill, but that opponents refer to as the “Don’t Say Gay” bill. It has become a national lightning rod in recent weeks, with President Biden calling the legislation “hateful.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rosalie R. Radomsky
title: In Clark Kent Mode, He Was Still Super Appealing
description: Kevin Rustagi was used to taking dates up in a plane or on a motorcycle. But to meet Katelyn Yeary, he arrived on crutches.
content: “You weren’t kidding when you said you were running a bit slow,” Katelyn Ann Yeary recalled saying to Kevin Ashok Rustagi when he showed up for their first date on crutches.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Zornosa
title: A Human-Size Spider Web Is Getting a Boost From TikTok
description: The “Tomás Saraceno: Particular Matter(s)” exhibition at the Shed — particularly the “Free the Air” installation — is drawing social media attention.
content: “You need to check out this installation in NYC,” reads the title card of the TikTok post.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: Justice Dept. to Expand Training Offered to Local Law Enforcement
description: The announcement comes as the administration has sought to fulfill a key part of President Biden’s legislative agenda.
content: BATON ROUGE, La. — Attorney General Merrick B. Garland said on Friday that the Justice Department would increase the training and other services it offered to local law enforcement agencies seeking to address policing problems, such as the use of excessive force, officer-involved shootings and police bias.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Rid
title: Why You Haven’t Heard About the Secret Cyberwar in Ukraine
description: The digital confrontation is playing out in the shadows, as inconspicuous as it is insidious.
content: “Cyberwar is coming!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: Shrugs Over Flu Signal Future Attitudes About Covid
description: The coronavirus pandemic hasn’t prompted most Americans to take influenza more seriously. Instead, more people are likely to think of Covid the way they think of flu, experts say.
content: When Dr. Arnold Monto, a public health researcher at the University of Michigan, lectures about influenza, he starts by saying: “Flu is bad.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ismay
title: Ukraine Is Wrecking Russian Tanks With a Gift From Britain
description: The NLAW antitank missile weighs about half as much as an American-made Javelin, costs far less and can be easily discarded after use.
content: In video after video taken in Ukraine, a puff of smoke and a brief flash of light signal that another clutch of Russian troops are about to die.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Russian Conductor Will Not Appear With New York Philharmonic
description: Tugan Sokhiev, who resigned from two posts after facing pressure to condemn the invasion of Ukraine, will not perform with the orchestra because of the war.
content: The Russian conductor Tugan Sokhiev, who recently resigned from two high-profile posts after facing pressure to condemn the Russian invasion of Ukraine, will no longer lead a series of concerts with the New York Philharmonic because of the war, the orchestra announced on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: These Dogs Are Also Firefighters’ Friends
description: The department is trying out four-legged robots to use in dangerous places. “These robots will save lives,” a fire captain said.
content: Good morning. It’s Friday. We’ll look at the New York Fire Department’s newest four-legged — not mascots, exactly. We’ll also preview the New York City Half Marathon, back on Sunday for the first time since 2019.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Casualties in the war in Ukraine.
content: A day after a Russian strike reduced to rubble a theater in Mariupol, Ukraine, where hundreds of people had been huddling for shelter, rescuers began pulling out survivors one by one. The southern city, under siege by Russian forces, has been squarely in Moscow’s cross hairs since the invasion began three weeks ago. Follow the latest updates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Allen
title: What Happened to One of Classical Music’s Most Popular Pieces?
description: César Franck’s only symphony was a pillar of the repertory for decades. But it’s now a rarity.
content: Whatever Leopold Stokowski’s thirst for celebrity, he was not known for caving to audience pressure. During his long tenure conducting the Philadelphia Orchestra, from 1912 to 1938, Stokowski gave the American premieres of scores as challenging as Stravinsky’s “Rite of Spring” and Berg’s “Wozzeck,” with little concern for box office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Justin Verlander Is Nowhere Near Done
description: “Can I do that? Yeah,” Verlander said, matter-of-factly, when asked about reaching 300 wins. An “aberration” among modern pitchers, it would be unwise to bet against him.
content: JUPITER, Fla. — Last to work 250 innings, next to earn 300 wins. That would be a fitting shorthand for the career of Justin Verlander, who has no plans to slow down any time soon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: How Useful Is It to Be Multilingual?
description: Do you speak multiple languages? Are you learning a new one? How has that knowledge expanded your world?
content: Do you speak, read or write in more than one language? Has knowing multiple languages helped you understand words better — their meanings, associations, pronunciations or spellings?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chung
title: Six Killed in Chain-Reaction Crash on Missouri Interstate
description: The collisions resulted in a pileup of more than a hundred vehicles and closed the highway in both directions, the authorities said.
content: A chain-reaction crash on an interstate in southeastern Missouri on Thursday morning left six people dead and resulted in a pileup of an estimated 135 vehicles, closing the highway in both directions for hours, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Carrns
title: Bringing Personal Finance to the Classroom for Generation Z
description: Twenty-three states require high schoolers to take the subject, and more could join them in an effort to boost the next generation’s financial literacy.
content: The number of states requiring high schoolers to learn about personal money matters continued to tick higher in 2021, and another — Florida — is poised to join the group shortly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: The Secret Is Out on This ‘Bridgerton’ Star
description: A few years ago, Nicola Coughlan was working in an optician’s office in Ireland. Now, with “Bridgerton” and “Derry Girls,” she’s starring in two of the most beloved shows on Netflix.
content: In January, right around her 35th birthday, the Irish actress Nicola Coughlan took what she called “a mega-holiday” — New York City, Austin, Hawaii, New York City again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Donatello Gets His Due
description: An exhibit in Florence puts the 16th century sculptor at the epicenter of the Renaissance, presenting a master whose innovations transformed art history.
content: FLORENCE, Italy — Walking about downtown Florence, a visitor inevitably happens upon the artistic legacy left by the Renaissance sculptor Donatello. Copies of his sculptures look down on passers-by from the bell tower of the city’s cathedral or from decorated niches along a main road, while originals populate churches and museums. Two works — the lion known as “Marzocco” and a statue of “Judith and Holofernes” — are installed in front of the Palazzo Vecchio, the city’s civic heart and a prestigious showcase for Florentine masterpieces like Michelangelo’s “David.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penn Bullock
title: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: Good evening. Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall and Andrew E. Kramer
title: Kyiv’s Suburbs Become Unlikely Front Line of Ukraine War
description: With savage artillery exchanges, the areas on the outskirts of the capital are the scenes of seesaw battles that have stalled the Russian advance for now.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — A tall woman with blonde and pink hair and a small dachshund stood out among the crowd of police officers and volunteers at the checkpoint on the edge of Kyiv. She looked as if she were out for a stroll, but she had just survived a dangerous evacuation under mortar fire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Av Westin, Newsman Behind ABC’s ‘20/20,’ Dies at 92
description: After nearly 20 years at CBS News, he went to a rival network and helped turn its answer to “60 Minutes” into a frequent Emmy Award winner.
content: Av Westin, an influential television producer who rose from copy boy at CBS News for Edward R. Murrow in the 1940s to help make ABC’s “20/20” newsmagazine a perennial winner of Emmy Awards, died on March 12 at a hospital in Manhattan. He was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi
title: Lawsuit Accuses Google of Bias Against Black Employees
description: The lawsuit echoes many of the complaints Black employees have expressed over the years about working at the company.
content: A former employee at Google sued the company on Friday, claiming it systematically discriminated against Black workers by placing them in lower-level jobs, underpaying them and denying them opportunities to advance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miya Lee
title: Love Letter: Intersecting Orbits
description: When an age difference pulls a couple in different directions.
content: They met when she was 45 and he was 32. They fell quickly for one another, celebrating every equinox and solstice by making love outside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: America Has a Free Speech Problem
description: A new poll finds Americans very anxious about the state of free speech.
content: For all the tolerance and enlightenment that modern society claims, Americans are losing hold of a fundamental right as citizens of a free country: the right to speak their minds and voice their opinions in public without fear of being shamed or shunned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall
title: For a Ukrainian Poet, Putin’s War Is All Too Familiar
description: Ihor Kalynets, 83, spent a lifetime resisting Soviet domination. Now, he says, he’s not going anywhere.
content: LVIV, Ukraine — At 83, no longer a young poet, Ihor Kalynets knows something of life under Russia’s thumb.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Peter Bowles, Actor in ‘To the Manor Born,’ Dies at 85
description: In a six-decade career in TV, film and onstage, he played comedy and drama, hapless heroes and villains, often with the air of the archetypal English gent.
content: Peter Bowles, a dapper British character actor who was best known for his role as an arriviste in the popular British television sitcom “To the Manor Born,” died on Thursday. He was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas
title: Brazil Blocks Telegram Over Disinformation Concerns
description: The Brazilian Supreme Court has vowed to fight disinformation ahead of this year’s presidential elections. Banning the popular messaging app is its most drastic step yet.
content: RIO DE JANEIRO — Brazil’s Supreme Court banned the fast-growing messaging app Telegram in the country on Friday, taking a drastic measure that showed the court plans to aggressively fight disinformation ahead of this year’s presidential elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: fecundity
description: This word has appeared in eight articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word fecundity has appeared in eight articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Dec. 17 in the Dance review “Getting Into the Tap Family Spirit With Two Stars as Hosts” by Brian Seibert:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: Dispatch From Hungary: The Man Trying to Return His Country to the Free World
description: The strongman’s ties to Putin might finally hurt him.
content: BUDAPEST — On Tuesday, the day that the prime ministers of Poland, the Czech Republic and Slovenia traveled to Kyiv to show solidarity with a besieged Ukraine, Viktor Orban, the prime minister of nearby Hungary, trumpeted his neutrality at a sprawling rally in Budapest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Cryptic Crossword
description: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon’s puzzle puts us on cloud nine.
content: CRYPTIC CROSSWORD — It’s always a nice surprise to see the Cox-Rathvon touch on a nonacrostic Sunday. This cryptic is typically whimsical, fun and squeaky clean, which in this context means that each clue is a neat little knot that unties itself without a lot of drama or extra string.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Emma Ashford
description: A conversation with foreign policy scholar Emma Ashford.
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Emma Ashford. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: Review: Gustavo Dudamel Wraps Up a Philharmonic Audition
description: The superstar conductor, a possible successor to the New York Philharmonic’s podium, led a cycle of Robert Schumann’s symphonies and two premieres.
content: If concerts had the “previously on” introductions of television, on Thursday the New York Philharmonic would have recapped last week’s installment of its Robert Schumann symphony cycle: lithe yet energetic, hardly Romantic yet fully alive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Naveen Kumar
title: Review: In ‘What You Are Now,’ Memory Is a Dangerous Thing
description: In Sam Chanse’s affecting play, a daughter tries to understand her mother, who resists any reminder of her escape from the Khmer Rouge.
content: Trying to understand our parents’ past lives can feel like fumbling through the dark, especially for the children of immigrants. Recollections are selective, and many people have lived through things they’d rather forget. The challenge — and heartbreak — of bridging that chasm is the subject of “What You Are Now,” an affecting study of memory and migration by the playwright Sam Chanse that opened on Thursday night at the Ensemble Studio Theater in Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Flitter
title: Where State Farm Sees ‘a Lot of Fraud,’ Black Customers See Discrimination
description: The giant insurer is facing lawsuits from customers, agents and former employees accusing it of racial discrimination.
content: It took years for Darryl Williams to build up the small real estate portfolio that became Connectors Realty, his business on the South Side of Chicago. In early 2017, when a pipe burst in his prized property — a building containing six apartments — Mr. Williams turned to his insurer, State Farm, to help repair the damage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronan Mckenzie and Eric McNeal
title: Easygoing Clothes in Shades of Cream and Khaki
description: Cocooning knits and enveloping jackets in neutral hues perfect for spring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon
title: Samoa locks down after recording a locally transmitted case.
description: The Pacific island nation of Samoa has closed its borders and prohibited public gatherings in a two-day national lockdown after recording its first known locally transmitted case of the coronavirus.
content: The Pacific island nation of Samoa has closed its borders and prohibited public gatherings in a two-day national lockdown after recording its first known locally transmitted case of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon
title: Hong Kong surpasses 1 million coronavirus cases, health officials say, amid a huge surge in deaths.
description: Hong Kong said that more than one million people in the city of 7.5 million had tested positive for the coronavirus since the beginning of the pandemic, a worrying milestone for a city being battered by an extraordinarily lethal Omicron wave.
content: Hong Kong said that more than one million people in the city of 7.5 million had tested positive for the coronavirus since the beginning of the pandemic, a worrying milestone for a city being battered by an extraordinarily lethal Omicron wave.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: How one energy company C.E.O. is trying to keep the lights on in Ukraine.
description: DTEK, a prominent Ukrainian power company, arranges for soldiers to escort its emergency repair crews to reach damaged transmission lines.
content: Keeping millions of customers in Ukraine supplied with electric power amid the Russian invasion is, to say the least, challenging. Especially when the electrical grid itself becomes a target.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane O'Neill
title: Will Smith Calls Bradley Cooper ‘Beautiful’ at Film Gala
description: “Licorice Pizza” was the big winner at the annual National Board of Review film awards.
content: The National Board of Review awards gala is not televised. This fact was announced onstage by its host Craig Melvin and giddily repeated by several guests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Gapes at Biden’s Calling Putin a ‘War Criminal’
description: A Kremlin spokesman pointed the finger back at the U.S. for World War II bombings, and Trevor Noah joked, “Keep up with the times, yo!”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope
title: Interrupted, Again: Suleika Jaouad on Cancer and Healing the Second Time Around
description: The popular writer of the “Life, Interrupted” column shares an update on her health and discusses how creativity and connection help her cope with life’s challenges.
content: In 2012, I asked a young writer named Suleika Jaouad to write the weekly “Life, Interrupted” column for The Times, about living with cancer in her early 20s after being diagnosed with an aggressive form of leukemia. The column captivated readers for more than two years, and a video series by the same name was honored with an Emmy Award in 2013.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tom Z. Collina
title: Why America Should Not Deepen Its Military Involvement in Ukraine
description: Any direct conflict between the United States and Russia could make this humanitarian crisis much worse.
content: In his stirring address to Congress on Wednesday, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine asked the United States for more help as his nation defends itself against a brutal and unjustified Russian invasion. Invoking the attacks on Pearl Harbor and the World Trade Center, Mr. Zelensky said simply, “I call on you to do more.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: ‘American Song Contest’ Puts a Stateside Spin on Eurovision
description: Stars vs. hopefuls. State vs. state. Eurovision fans will recognize the format of NBC’s new original song competition. For everyone else, here’s a primer.
content: Hosted by Kelly Clarkson and Snoop Dogg, the eight-week reality competition “American Song Contest,” scheduled to premiere Monday on NBC, is totally new.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William P. Davis
title: Stocks notch their best week since November 2020.
description: Some of the pressures that had combined to sour once-ebullient markets seemed to be easing.
content: Oil prices slid and the Federal Reserve offered investors clarity on its plan to tame inflation, triggering a rally that pushed stocks to their best week in more than a year.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Robot Dogs Join New York Fire Department, Which Promises a Short Leash
description: Quotation of the Day for: Friday, March 18, 2022.
content: “The TV industry and the movie industry are hurting us in some ways because they often show pictures of robots that are weaponized, and then people think that’s how all robots are.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin, Alan Blinder and Natalie Weiner
title: N.C.A.A. Women’s Tournament: South Carolina Is Still Quite Dominant
description: The top-seeded Gamecocks led 44-4 at halftime and finished just as strongly. Florida Gulf Coast, a big upset pick, beat Virginia Tech.
content: COLUMBIA, S.C. — South Carolina has set the bar exceedingly high.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: An economic decline is coming, Russia’s central bank chief says.
description: Inflation and “large-scale structural transformation” are ahead, as the bank held interest rates at 20 percent.
content: Russia’s central bank governor, Elvira Nabiullina, said on Friday that the country’s economy would decline in the coming quarters and that inflation would jump further as sanctions imposed after the invasion of Ukraine took their toll. Earlier, the bank’s board of directors held interest rates at 20 percent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Betty Hallock
title: Can Scent Be Democratized?
description: The Institute for Art and Olfaction celebrates a decade of exploring our sense of smell.
content: On a recent evening, masked students sat around stainless-steel tables in the scent lab at the Institute for Art and Olfaction in Los Angeles’s Chinatown, pipettes at the ready. The LED glow from shelves that hold nearly 400 bottles of perfumers’ materials cast a backlit-bar vibe over the first in-person studio class since the latest Covid spike. An aromatic cocktail of norlimbanol, vanillin and myrrh suffused the atmosphere, permeating even a KF94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: Mail Ballot Rejections Surge in Texas, With Signs of a Race Gap
description: A new Republican voting law led to the sharp rise in rejected ballots in the state’s recent primary election. An analysis shows that Black areas of Houston disproportionately had votes thrown out.
content: More than 18,000 voters in Texas’ most populous counties had their mail-in ballots rejected in the state’s primary election this month, according to a review of election data by The New York Times, a surge in thrown-out votes that disproportionately affected Black people in the state’s largest county and revealed the impact of new voting regulations passed by Republicans last year.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Science Behind Mental Afflictions
description: Sara Manning Peskin talks about “A Molecule Away From Madness,” and J. Kenji López-Alt discusses “The Wok.”
content: In “A Molecule Away From Madness,” the neurologist Sara Manning Peskin writes about the errant molecular activity that underlies many serious mental afflictions. Peskin’s book, reminiscent of the work of Oliver Sacks, conveys its scientific information through narrative.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia and Josh Holder
title: Russia’s military progress slows, but it makes gains in the south and east.
description: Britain’s defense intelligence service said that Russian forces had “made minimal progress this week.”
content: Even as a missile strike on Friday hit the outskirts of Lviv, a Ukrainian city that had been spared much of the Russian assault, the latest intelligence assessments indicate that Russian forces are still struggling to capture more territory as they try to push across Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe and Nancy Wartik
title: Back-to-Office Carrots and Sticks
description: Some companies are wooing workers, but not all.
content: For the last two years, 50 million Americans have been part of a live experiment in remote work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siddharth Sridhar
title: Why Omicron Is So Deadly in Hong Kong
description: Low vaccination rates among the elderly have created a perfect storm.
content: HONG KONG — For most of the Covid pandemic, life in Hong Kong remained a simulacrum of normal. The city maintained one of the world’s strictest border control measures, requiring inbound travelers to undergo quarantine in hotels for up to three weeks. Small waves of cases were quickly stopped with exhaustive contact tracing, strict hospital-based isolation and supervised quarantine in designated facilities. Mask mandates were introduced but were hardly necessary; masks, for the most part, have been spontaneously adopted by the general public since early 2020. This frenetic city of 7.5 million never locked down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Vrentas and Emmanuel Morgan
title: Deshaun Watson Agrees to Trade to the Cleveland Browns
description: The former quarterback of the Houston Texans missed last season as he faced a criminal investigation and lawsuits involving sexual misconduct. A grand jury last week declined to charge him.
content: A week after a Harris County, Texas, grand jury rejected nine criminal cases against him, Deshaun Watson agreed to waive his no-trade clause to facilitate a trade to the Cleveland Browns from the Houston Texans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: People shrug over flu. Will they soon be shrugging about Covid?
description: In good years, flu kills Americans in the low tens of thousands and sickens many times more. Yet even in the time of Covid, flu, the other respiratory killer caused by a virus, is underestimated. Almost half of American adults don’t bother to get vaccinated against it. Despite the ongoing Covid experience, researchers and historians don’t expect Americans’ attitudes toward flu to change much.
content: In good years, flu kills Americans in the low tens of thousands and sickens many times more. Yet even in the time of Covid, flu, the other respiratory killer caused by a virus, is underestimated. Almost half of American adults don’t bother to get vaccinated against it. Despite the ongoing Covid experience, researchers and historians don’t expect Americans’ attitudes toward flu to change much.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Seminara
title: Hidden Tampa: The Best of an Often-Overlooked Florida City
description: From a Buddhist temple reached by boat to a storied hotel and a speakeasy bar: a cheat sheet on what to do in this Gulf Coast city, which has found new fans during the pandemic.
content: I live 15 minutes from Tampa, Fla., but I hardly ever visited the Gulf Coast city when I moved to nearby St. Petersburg in 2019. My friends in St. Pete dismissed the place as a sprawling, sun-baked collection of strip malls, and the traffic on the Gandy and Howard Frankland bridges connecting the two cities was an incentive to stay on “our” side of the bay. Then the pandemic came and with it more time in the area and a lot less traffic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson
title: Confusion and Chaos in Hong Kong as Leaders Fumble Virus Response
description: Government officials have been unable to curb an outbreak that has surpassed one million infections, leading Beijing to step up its intervention in the semiautonomous territory.
content: HONG KONG — From week to week as infections barreled through the city, residents in Hong Kong watched the government’s coronavirus policies change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Barry
title: How Long Should It Take to Grieve? Psychiatry Has Come Up With an Answer.
description: The latest edition of the DSM-5, sometimes known as “psychiatry’s bible,” includes a controversial new diagnosis: prolonged grief disorder.
content: After more than a decade of argument, psychiatry’s most powerful body in the United States added a new disorder this week to its diagnostic manual: prolonged grief.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: Climate change is making armed conflict worse. Here’s how.
description: Warming is “unambiguously worsening” conditions that contribute to clashes and deepen the pain for civilians, a new study says.
content: If you’ve read the work of brave journalists in Mariupol this week, you know that the people of that city are trying to survive not just shelling by Russian forces. They are also trying to survive without water.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rosemary Howe Camozzi
title: On (Not) Wasting My Time With a Younger Man
description: We had no future together, so why not fall completely in love?
content: We were almost to the bridge over the I-5 freeway in Eugene, Ore., when he said, “How old are you?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: 6 Injured as Powerful Storms Tear Through the South
description: A violent storm damaged nine mobile homes in Atmore, Ala. “It looked like all the trailers just exploded,” a sheriff said of the scene.
content: Powerful storms moved through Alabama and Florida on Friday, injuring six people, damaging several mobile homes and taking out power lines, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Dr. Oz’s Heritage Is Targeted as Rivals Vie for Trump Backing
description: The Senate candidate’s Turkish background has emerged as a focus of David McCormick’s attacks in Pennsylvania’s G.O.P. primary.
content: Late last year, before he had formally entered the Pennsylvania Senate race, David McCormick flew to Florida for a private meeting with Donald J. Trump, angling to get in the former president’s good graces ahead of a Republican primary that would soon pit him against Dr. Mehmet Oz, the celebrity surgeon and television personality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ligaya Mishan, Anthony Cotsifas and Victoria Petro-Conroy
title: In a Starving World, Is Eating Well Unethical?
description: A meditation on the true cost of dining when nearly one-third of the planet lacks regular access to food.
content: MIDAS IS IN the kitchen. A tomahawk steak gleams, leafed in 24-karat gold, with only the long handle of the bone left bare. When pierced with a knife, the gilded slab reveals itself to be actual meat, mottled pink and swaddled in fat. Steam rises, as from a fresh kill. Such a steak — a signature of the Turkish chef Nusret Gokce, better known as Salt Bae — appears in a video that went viral last November, in which Gokce himself delivers the golden calf to the table of General To Lam, the Vietnamese minister of public security, at Nusr-Et steakhouse in London. The chef slices and slaps the cuts of meat so they tumble like dominoes, then stabs one with the tip of his knife and reaches it across the table toward his high-ranking guest. The general opens his mouth and accepts the bite as if it were his due.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jori Finkel
title: In Her Last Works, Kaari Upson Explores Vanity and Decay
description: The artist, who probed the depths of psychic trauma, left behind elusive new portraits that will debut at the Venice Biennale.
content: LOS ANGELES — On a visit last month to Kaari Upson’s studio here, it looked like she just left to grab a cup of coffee or maybe one of the “garbage burritos” she loved so much. Her art was everywhere: new paintings and drawings covering the walls, with recent sculptures of tree trunks — made to look like knobby-kneed legs — hanging from the ceiling. Outside, on the back patio, was a used mattress — one of her favorite objects for casting in silicone because of its associations with trash, sex and sickbeds. Her pickup truck, a gray Toyota Tundra, was still parked in back. The whiteboard on the wall still had to-do notes in her handwriting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Abrams
title: Brittney Griner Said to Be ‘OK’ as Russian Court Extends Her Detention
description: Griner, the W.N.B.A. star, has been detained on drug charges in Russia since mid-February and is now expected to remain in custody until at least May.
content: A Russian court extended the detention of the W.N.B.A. star Brittney Griner by two months on Thursday, and denied an appeal from her legal team, who had hoped to have her transferred to house arrest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Hoping to Identify Cheaters, a Professor Sues His Own Students
description: David Berkovitz, who teaches business law at Chapman University in Orange, Calif., sued an unnamed group of his students — identified only as “Does” — after he discovered that his midterm and final exams had been uploaded to a popular website.
content: One professor is going to unusual lengths to identify the students who he believes cheated in his class: He is suing them in federal court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Kasakove
title: Cities Move to Sever ‘Sister City’ Ties With Russian Governments
description: Some city officials say ending ties sends a message condemning the invasion of Ukraine. Others say the best way to have an effect is to use the ties that already exist.
content: At the height of the Cold War, as the deep chill in diplomatic relations between the United States and the Soviet Union persisted, pairs of cities across both countries embraced an idealistic mission: to form cultural and political bonds as “sister cities.” Now, with Russia’s invasion of Ukraine in its fourth bloody week, those ties appear to be fraying as never before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: U.S. warns servicing or refueling some Russian-owned planes may violate trade restrictions.
description: Export controls introduced in late February prohibit exporting aircraft that were made in the U.S. or use some U.S. parts to Russia, effectively grounding some international flights, the Commerce Department said.
content: The Commerce Department said on Friday that it had identified 100 commercial and private aircraft that violated U.S. export controls by flying into Russia and that their owners, operators and servicers were at risk of substantial jail time, fines, loss of export privileges or other restrictions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Jack Willis, TV Producer and Empathetic Filmmaker, Dies at 87
description: A survivor of a crippling accident, his documentaries and news coverage for public television focused on poverty, race and other social issues.
content: Jack Willis, a journalist and television executive who won several Emmys and a Polk Award for his innovative films and news and documentary programming during the embryonic years of cable and public broadcasting, died on Feb. 9 in Zurich. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giulia Heyward
title: Fatal Texas Wildfire Forces Evacuations and Destroys 50 Homes
description: The Eastland Complex fire has killed one person and burned more than 45,000 acres in the central part of the state, officials said.
content: At least one person was killed, 50 homes were destroyed and nearly 500 others evacuated in central Texas after a wildfire burned more than 45,000 acres, officials said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Candace Jackson
title: When Your Second Home Is the First One You Buy
description: Some hopeful homeowners are keeping their rentals in pricey, urban areas, but are buying second homes in more affordable, rural and suburban locations.
content: Lillie Walsh Dudley and Andy Dudley wanted to be homeowners. The couple, who have a 5-year-old son, had been renting in South Slope since 2014. They began looking for something to buy about three years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Berger
title: Rabbi Chaim Kanievsky, Venerated Talmudic Scholar, Dies at 94
description: He initially insisted, “Canceling Torah study is more dangerous than the coronavirus.” But he had a change of heart, even before testing positive.
content: Rabbi Chaim Kanievsky, one of the greatest Talmudic interpreters of his generation and one of the most revered figures among the world’s ultra-Orthodox Jews, who considered him the leading authority on fine points of Jewish law, died on Friday in the Israeli city of Bnei Brak, near Tel Aviv. He was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter
title: National Book Critics Circle Names 2021 Award Winners
description: Honorée Fanonne Jeffers, Clint Smith, Rebecca Donner and Anthony Veasna So were among the winners.
content: Anthony Veasna So’s short-story collection “Afterparties,” which centers on the lives of Cambodian Americans in California, won the National Book Critics Circle Award for best debut book on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Min Jin Lee
title: Asian Americans Have Always Lived With Fear
description: In my decades growing up in New York, survival required constant vigilance. Sadly, very little has changed.
content: Earlier this month, I took an informal poll on social media to ask Asians and Asian Americans how they had altered their daily lives in response to the recent rise of assaults against us. I heard from hundreds of women and men, young and old, who described their workarounds — the extra steps they have been taking to stay physically safe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber
title: Colleges Can Avoid Shutting the Door on Financial Aid Knowledge
description: We review Whitman College’s financial aid guarantee and Muhlenberg College’s refreshing explainer.
content: This month, scores of applicants to Muhlenberg and Whitman Colleges received offers of admission. Perhaps they were a pleasant surprise for students who had sleepZoomed their way through junior year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Edward Wong
title: Biden Warns China of ‘Consequences’ if It Aids Russia in Ukraine War
description: President Biden told China’s leader, Xi Jinping, there would be consequences if Beijing gave material support to Russia, implying that the United States could impose sanctions on China.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden warned President Xi Jinping of China on Friday of “implications and consequences” if Beijing decides to give material aid to Russia to support its war in Ukraine, the White House said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cecilia Kang
title: A judge throws out D.C.’s attempt to name Zuckerberg in a privacy lawsuit.
description: D.C.’s attorney general had waited too long to add Mark Zuckerberg as a defendant in the suit against Meta, the judge said.
content: A judge on Tuesday threw out motions by the attorney general of the District of Columbia to name Mark Zuckerberg, the chief executive of Meta, as a defendant in a privacy lawsuit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing and Stephen Gandel
title: How the War in Ukraine Could Slow the Sales of Electric Cars
description: The price of nickel, an essential ingredient in most batteries, has soared because of fear that Russian supplies could be cut off.
content: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has shaken the global market for nickel just as the metal gains importance as an ingredient in electric car batteries, raising fears that high prices could slow the transition away from fossil fuels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica Ackerberg and Natalie Proulx
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘Why Do We Change the Clocks, Anyway?’
description: The Senate recently passed legislation that would make daylight saving time permanent. In this lesson, students will look at the history of this ritual and decide if they support the bill.
content: Featured Article: “Why Do We Change the Clocks, Anyway?” by Alan Yuhas
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tanner Greer
title: Ukraine’s Cause Is Righteous. That Shouldn’t Shape Policy.
description: The Iraq war showed us how dangerous policy driven by moral imperatives can be.
content: The Russian invasion of Ukraine has transformed the face of global geopolitics. Two weeks ago, the West stood distracted, uncertain and divided; now it has embarked on a determined, even frenzied, effort to stymie Russian power. The list of Western actions grows longer by the day: Some 20 countries have sent weapons to Ukraine. More than 17,000 foreign-supplied antitank weapons now flood the battlefield. Even more countries have united to levy more than 3,600 sanctions against Russian individuals and companies. Seven of Russia’s largest banks have been removed from the SWIFT interbank messaging system. The dollar and euro reserves of the Russian central bank have been frozen. American, Canadian and European airspaces have been closed to all Russian planes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Marin Hinkle of ‘The Marvelous Mrs. Maisel’ Melts Chocolate
description: The television actress, who is filming the show’s fifth and final season, learned to make truffles.
content: “It’s very smooth,” the actress Marin Hinkle said, her eyes closed in apparent bliss.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gary Phillips
title: The First Designated Hitter Is Ready for the Universal D.H.
description: Ron Blomberg was a curiosity when he took the pitcher’s spot in the batting order in 1973. Now it will be standard practice in both leagues. “They should have done this a long time ago.”
content: On April 6, 1973, two letters changed Ron Blomberg’s life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: NASA’s Giant Moon Rocket Reaches the Launchpad for the First Time
description: NASA rolled the giant Space Launch System rocket out of an assembly building to begin testing ahead of its journey later this year toward the moon.
content: NASA’s giant new moon rocket is finally at the launchpad, although it is yet to be determined when it might finally leave Earth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles, Giovanni Russonello and Lindsay Zoladz
title: Arcade Fire Ignites a Fresh Era, and 11 More New Songs
description: Hear tracks by Normani, Brad Mehldau, Valerie June and others.
content: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilary Sheinbaum
title: She Sells Cookie Dough That’s Better for You
description: Sabeena Ladha is the founder of Deux, a raw cookie dough that is vegan and gluten-free.
content: Name: Sabeena Ladha
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson, Megan Specia and Edward Wong
title: Russia Targets Western Ukraine as Biden Warns Xi Not to Aid Moscow
description: A scramble of diplomatic efforts bears little fruit as Russia intensifies its attacks, including with a bombardment into a relatively unscathed part of western Ukraine.
content: Russian forces extended their bombardments into a relatively unscathed part of western Ukraine on Friday, striking a warplane repair plant about 50 miles from the Polish border, as President Biden warned President Xi Jinping of China not to provide military aid to Russia amid a scramble of diplomatic efforts to end the violence engulfing Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe
title: D.C. Suit Accusing Amazon of Controlling Prices Is Thrown Out
description: The attorney general for the District of Columbia said Amazon made merchants on its site sell at the lowest price they charged on the web, resulting in higher prices overall.
content: A court on Friday threw out what was thought to have been the first government lawsuit in the United States arguing that Amazon had broken antitrust laws.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Trump Campaign Owes $300,000 in Legal Fees After Another Failed NDA Case
description: The award stems from an arbitration claim that was dismissed in part because of the “vague and unenforceable” provisions of a nondisclosure agreement.
content: Donald J. Trump’s presidential campaign has been ordered to pay more than $300,000 in legal fees and expenses to a former employee who the campaign’s lawyers said had violated the terms of a nondisclosure agreement when she accused Mr. Trump of forcibly kissing her in 2016.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: War in Ukraine Prompts a Political Makeover in Poland
description: Jaroslaw Kaczynski, Poland’s de facto leader and longtime scourge of E.U. unity, is portraying himself as a standard-bearer of European solidarity in defense of Ukraine and democratic values.
content: WARSAW — After years of cozying up to Kremlin-friendly anti-immigrant firebrands and fulminating against the European Union, the leader of Poland’s populist governing party has taken on an unlikely new role: a standard-bearer of European solidarity in defense of Ukraine and democratic values.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: A Realist Take on How the Russia-Ukraine War Could End
description: In a conversation that carries a glimmer of hope, the foreign policy scholar Emma Ashford considers possible paths to de-escalation.
content: As we enter the fourth week of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, many of the possible pathways this conflict could take are terrifying. A military quagmire that leads to protracted death and suffering. A Russian takeover of Kyiv and installation of a puppet government. An accidental strike on Polish or Romanian territory that draws America and the rest of NATO into war. Or, perhaps worst of all, a series of escalations that culminates in nuclear exchange.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marisa Ingemi
title: For I.U.P.U.I., a Second Chance at a First Impression
description: The university’s women’s basketball program earned its first N.C.A.A. tournament bid in 2020, but the pandemic intruded. Back in the bracket, the Jaguars are anticipating their matchup with Oklahoma.
content: Ten players and coaches for Indiana University-Purdue University Indianapolis had experienced what it was like to make the N.C.A.A. tournament in 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leah Askarinam and Blake Hounshell
title: Politics Still Pushes Buttons. This One Sold for $185,850.
description: The political button business has been booming. A Cox/Roosevelt campaign button from 1920 was auctioned for a six-figure sum this week.
content: Ted Hake has seen his fair share of memorable campaign tokens since he started his auction business, Hake’s Auctions, in 1967. The peanut-shaped fishing lure with a mouth shaped like Jimmy Carter’s toothy smile stands out. There are also campaign cigars, bottles, plates and lots of ribbons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grant Snider
title: Recommended Reading
description: “500 Books You’re a Fool for Not Having Read Already” and more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Miller
title: Texas Tech’s Unusual Defense Stifles Montana State
description: The Red Raiders blew out the Bobcats in the round of 64 in the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament.
content: SAN DIEGO — Coach Danny Sprinkle sort of already knew what his Montana State Bobcats would be in for on Friday. But just in case, as Sprinkle made the rounds doing prep work, a Big 12 coach whom he didn’t name made sure to remind him of Texas Tech’s threat: “They’re as real as it gets.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg and Lananh Nguyen
title: As Offices Open and Mask Mandates Drop, Some Anxieties Set In
description: Using local guidelines, many companies are loosening Covid safety rules, leaving workers to navigate masking and social distancing on their own.
content: Employers are embracing a workplace atmosphere reminiscent of prepandemic times — elevators jammed, snack tables brimming, face coverings optional — even as a new subvariant of the Omicron coronavirus spurs concerns about health and safety. Across the country, office occupancy has hit a pandemic high, 40 percent, reached just once before in early December, at the same time that indoor mask mandates drop.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Love Letters to California
description: The state might be drought-stricken, fire-ridden and wildly expensive, but our readers love it all the same.
content: It’s been a long week, so this morning I’m offering a little serotonin boost to carry us into the weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley
title: Defying China’s Censors to Urge Beijing to Denounce Russia’s War
description: A persistent minority of Chinese scholars, journalists and citizens is warning Beijing against the risks of supporting the invasion of Ukraine.
content: When Hu Wei, a politically well-connected scholar in Shanghai, warned that China risked becoming a pariah if it didn’t denounce Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, he ignited a war of words on China’s internet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: With Zero Notice, U.K. Ferry Company Lays Off Hundreds of Workers Over Video
description: The abrupt terminations caused widespread service cancellations and drew immediate backlash from government officials and unions.
content: LONDON — A British ferry company laid off 800 people with immediate effect on Thursday, many of them over video, leading to international travel disruptions and condemnation by government officials over its plan to cut service and replace staff with cheaper labor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: ‘Texas Chain Saw Massacre’ and the Lessons Few Horror Films Get Right
description: Ti West is the rare genre director to understand the original and honor it with a movie, “X,” that also works on its own terms.
content: Fifteen years ago, I sat down with 20 or so of the most prolific serial killers in the world, responsible for hundreds of stabbings, decapitations and other unspeakable murders — and was absolutely charmed. A get-together of directors of scary movies, including Wes Craven, Eli Roth, Larry Cohen, Don Coscarelli and Robert Rodriguez, this event, semi-jokingly referred to as “the masters of horror dinner,” was giddily jovial. Just as comedians tend to be more serious in person than you expect, horror artists are, generally speaking, very funny.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catrin Einhorn and Lisa Friedman
title: Nations Should Conserve Fuel as Global Energy Crisis Looms, Agency Warns
description: The International Energy Agency said countries should encourage use of mass transit and car pooling, among other things. That could also help the climate crisis.
content: The war in Ukraine is setting into motion the first global energy crisis of its kind, and nations around the world should respond by reducing their use of oil and gas, the leader of a key international organization warned on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Fisher
title: Russia’s Brutality in Ukraine Has Roots in Earlier Conflicts
description: Its experience in a string of wars led to the conclusion that attacking civilian populations was not only acceptable but militarily sound.
content: As Russian artillery and rockets land on Ukrainian hospitals and apartment blocks, devastating residential districts with no military value, the world is watching with horror what is, for Russia, an increasingly standard practice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Pope Deplores the War in Ukraine but Not the Aggressor
description: Francis has raised his voice against “unacceptable armed aggression” without mentioning President Vladimir V. Putin or Russia. Some analysts say that he risks complicating his legacy.
content: ROME — The day after Russia invaded Ukraine, Pope Francis broke protocol and went directly to the Russian Embassy in the Holy See to appeal for peace. The next day he spoke to President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine, offering him spiritual support. As the war intensified, he raised his voice against “unacceptable armed aggression” and the “barbarism of the killing of children.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives and Makiko Inoue
title: A ‘Killing Stone’ Broke in Japan. Is a Demon on the Loose?
description: The rock appears in a famous legend starring a nine-tailed fox spirit. The question now is whether the fracture was a good or bad omen.
content: With so much going wrong in the world, should we now also worry about a nine-tailed fox demoness that may be loose in a forest in Japan?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Cut the Gas Tax? No, No, No.
description: There are better ways to help people squeezed by inflation.
content: There’s an understandable groundswell of support for suspending gasoline taxes. High prices at the pump are causing pain for Americans, and most states are in good financial condition, so they can afford to give something back to the people. Strategas Securities, an investment research firm, counts 22 states that are considering some sort of full or partial suspension of gasoline taxes. There are also proposals to suspend the federal excise tax on gasoline.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger and Patrick Kingsley
title: As diplomacy drags on, peace seems far off in Ukraine.
description: Western officials have little optimism that talks between Russia and Ukraine have reached a serious stage or have even confronted the most difficult issues.
content: BRUSSELS — Ukraine and Russia are engaged in intermittent negotiations to end a brutal war now in its third week. But despite signs of progress, Western officials have little optimism that the talks have reached a serious stage or even confronted the most difficult issues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Li Yuan
title: China’s Information Dark Age Could Be Russia’s Future
description: Russia and China have the tendency to learn the worst from each other: tyrants, famines, purges and, now, internet censorship.
content: When Russia blocked Facebook and limited Twitter this month, many Chinese internet users were surprised. Wait a moment, they said: The Russians could use Facebook and Twitter? Both social media platforms have been banned in China since 2009.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Covid and the ‘Very Liberal’
description: There’s a schism among Democrats. And the latest on Ukraine.
content: The left-right divide over Covid-19 — with blue America taking the virus more seriously than red America — has never been the pandemic’s only political divide. Each partisan tribe has also had its internal disagreements.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: At Indian Wells, Spain’s Nadal and Alcaraz Meet in Men’s Semifinal
description: One is a champion many times over who is enjoying a late-career revival. The other is a newcomer overflowing with potential who is quickly closing the gap.
content: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — Rafael Nadal, who had just defused Nick Kyrgios in three tense sets to reach the semifinals of the BNP Paribas Open, was trying to focus on the questions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Biden Warns China
description: In a two-hour call, the president told Xi Jinping there would be “consequences” if China provides aid to Russia.
content: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miguel Salazar
title: New in Paperback: ‘The Copenhagen Trilogy,’ ‘Tom Stoppard: A Life’ and More
description: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
content: THE COPENHAGEN TRILOGY: Childhood; Youth; Dependency,  by Tove Ditlevsen. Translated by Tiina Nunnally and Michael Favala Goldman. (Picador, 384 pp., $20.) This collection of Ditlevesen’s memoirs, first published in Denmark in the 1960s and ’70s, describes her impoverished upbringing, career path and unsparing addictions. This “unstinting account of the struggle to reconcile art and life,” as our reviewer, Megan O’Grady, called it, was one of the Book Review’s 10 Best Books of 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Mark Meadows’s 2020 Vote Is Under Investigation in North Carolina
description: Records show that Mr. Meadows cast an absentee ballot from the address of a remote mobile home, but reports have cast doubt on whether he lived there.
content: North Carolina officials said on Thursday that they planned to investigate whether Mark Meadows, who as former President Donald J. Trump’s chief of staff helped amplify false claims of voter fraud in an attempt to overturn the 2020 election, cast a legal vote in that year’s presidential race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: The Many Uses (and Abuses) of Shame
description: Cathy O’Neil’s “The Shame Machine” is the most recent book to address an emotion that can be exhilarating or terrifying, depending on where you sit.
content: When we experience shame, we feel bad; and when we inflict shame, we feel good. Those seem to be among the few points of consensus when it comes to what the historian Peter N. Stearns calls a “disputed emotion.” Unlike fear or anger, shame is “self-conscious”; it doesn’t erupt so much as coil around itself. It requires an awareness of others and their disapproval, and it has to be learned. Aristotle thought of it as fundamental to ethical behavior; Confucius saw it as essential to social order.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: Kids, Covid Isolation and Learning to Endure
description: The virus found us, and we’re doing just fine. I think.
content: SYDNEY, Australia — We’re binge-buying rapid antigen tests for immediate delivery. We get all our food left at the front door and keep masks in every room. I’ve even revived the indoor exercise regimen from my 14-day stint in Australia’s remote quarantine camp.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: At P.S.G., Kylian Mbappé Has to Go
description: Mbappé is a generational talent who deserves a bigger stage on a weekly basis than the one Paris St.-Germain can offer.
content: Only one player escaped the ire of the Parc des Princes. Paris St.-Germain’s fans whistled and jeered every time Lionel Messi touched the ball. They howled and crowed at the sight of a wayward shot from Neymar. There was no allowance in their anger for reputation, no discrimination by status. It encompassed mortal and immortal alike.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Zagoria
title: After Vanquishing Basketball Royalty, St. Peter’s Celebrates
description: The small Jesuit university in Jersey City is in high spirits after eliminating Kentucky, a basketball blue blood, from the N.C.A.A. men’s tournament.
content: JERSEY CITY, N.J. — Farouk Sow, a junior at St. Peter’s University, was walking down a set of stairs from the university bridge running across John F. Kennedy Boulevard here on Friday morning when he spotted a blue “ABC 7 Eyewitness News” van on the street. Nearby, a video screen on a wall flashed an image of four members of the school’s men’s basketball team celebrating and holding a blue “March Madness” sign.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Morning: ‘Very liberal’ Americans are the most worried about Covid, polling shows.
description: In today’s edition of The Morning newsletter, David Leonhardt writes about the Covid schism among Democrats.
content: In today’s edition of The Morning newsletter, David Leonhardt writes about the Covid schism among Democrats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Ng
title: Exploring the Diversity, and Precariousness, of French Stand-Up
description: Fanny Herrero, the creator of “Call My Agent!,” returns with a Netflix show called “Standing Up,” which follows four struggling Parisian comics.
content: PARIS — In the opening scenes of “Standing Up,” Nezir (Younès Boucif) mines his life for stand-up material as he cycles across Paris on a food delivery shift.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Five Science Fiction Movies to Stream Now
description: This month’s picks include near-future psychological drama, Oscar-nominated robot antics and a bearded, mysterious Hugo Weaving.
content: The Australian director Ivan Sen has been on the radar of genre aficionados since “Mystery Road” (2013) and “Goldstone” (2016), two successful hybrids of procedural and western revolving around the charismatic figure of a taciturn Indigenous detective. For his latest, Sen mixed science fiction and noir, with a dollop of romance thrown in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Pete Davidson No Longer Going to Space, Blue Origin Says
description: According to the company, the comedian is “no longer able to join” its coming mission. It was unclear whether another celebrity would take his seat.
content: Pete Davidson, the “Saturday Night Live” comedian and actor, will no longer travel to the edge of space on the next Blue Origin spaceflight, the company said late Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: How Oni and Uché Blackstock, Doctors, Spend Their Sundays
description: The twin sisters, who have been go-to experts during the pandemic, are outspoken on racial inequities in health care.
content: Oni and Uché Blackstock, 44, are twin sisters and Harvard-educated doctors who have been on the front lines of the pandemic. Both run businesses that address racial inequity in health care. And both are divorced parents of sons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced and Ephrat Livni
title: Is the Nickel Market Broken?
description: The chaos in trading of the metal could have broad implications.
content: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has shaken many markets, perhaps none as severely as trading in nickel. The chaos is causing supply problems for carmakers and others that need the metal — and raising fundamental questions about how commodity markets work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Michael Simon Johnson, Eric Krupke, Kaitlin Roberts, Patricia Willens, Marc Georges, Paige Cowett, Chris Wood and Marion Lozano
title: The Global Race to Mine the Metal of the Future
description: The quest for cobalt, which is essential for electric-car batteries, has fueled a cycle of exploitation, greed and gamesmanship.
content: In the high-stakes competition to dominate the business of clean energy, the Democratic Republic of Congo is a major arena: The country is the source of more than two-thirds of the world’s cobalt, a key component of electric-car batteries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘Windfall’ Review: Money Talks
description: A wealthy couple is detained by an incompetent thief in this airless Netflix drama.
content: If you can remain awake until the final moments of “Windfall,” then yes, something exciting actually happens. But that’s a very long wait in Charlie McDowell’s oppressive Netflix drama, a gabby hostage movie with a single, covetable location and three unappealing characters.
source.name: The New York Times

description: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

author: By Yousur Al-Hlou, Masha Froliak, Brent McDonald, Mark Boyer and Benjamin Foley
title: In Irpin, a Last-ditch Effort to Evacuate From Russian Attacks
description: As fighting intensifies northwest of Kyiv, Ukraine, volunteer medics are risking their lives to try to rescue the last remaining residents in Irpin. Our cameras joined them on the three-mile journey.
content: As fighting intensifies northwest of Kyiv, Ukraine, volunteer medics are risking their lives to try to rescue the last remaining residents in Irpin. Our cameras joined them on the three-mile journey.

author: By The Associated Press and Storyful
title: Missiles Strike Airport Complex in Lviv, Officials Say
description: Officials in Lviv, a city in western Ukraine, said Russian missiles hit an aircraft-repair plant about four miles from the city center. Attacks in western Ukraine have been rare since the war began.
content: Officials in Lviv, a city in western Ukraine, said Russian missiles hit an aircraft-repair plant about four miles from the city center. Attacks in western Ukraine have been rare since the war began.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: March 18, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, March 18, 2022.
content: A picture caption with an article on Wednesday about the search for Ernest Shackleton’s ship Endurance, using information provided by the photo agency, misidentified the location shown. The cross atop a stone cairn in Grytviken on the island of South Georgia is a memorial to Shackleton. His grave is elsewhere in the settlement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Weekend
description: Eric Kim’s recipe for milk bread will provide ham and mayonnaise sandwiches (and more) for days.
content: Good morning. Eric Kim brought us a new recipe for milk bread (above) this week, along with a powerful argument for making it. The process, he wrote, “invites me to shut off my brain, to stop tinkering. I’ve found that when I make time for this bread, with its two rises, each an hour or more, I’m also making time to take a bath, time to read a book, time to pour myself a glass of wine (usually all three). It feels as if I’m lengthening the day beyond its 24 hours.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transgender Youths Become a Political Issue in Texas
description: The transgender youth controversy in Texas; the “Don’t Say Gay” bill in Florida; U.S. policy and North Korea.
